title: Serif — New Century Schoolbook?
content:
Hello,  
wondering what this font is called?  
A New Century Schoolbook version?  
Thanks in advance!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317114556im_/http:/typophile.com/files/999252_1376043092609666_527163090_n_3544.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317114556im_/http:/typophile.com/files/1005065_1376042899276352_1442928134_n_5284.jpg)

Font: 

 Old Style 7 

Solved By: 

 [fvilanakis](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317114556/http:/typophile.com/user/176276 "View user profile.")
author: Emma-L

comments.content:
It looks like **[Old Style 7](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317114556/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=Linotype&ffam=Old%20Style%207%20Std%20-%20Roman&fid=ad65b6f4fc969c2cd0b186b86d1d7135&fsize=60&text=livres%2C%20musique%2C%20en%20pise%20de%20Tarik%20Hayward&wrap=2)** available from Linotype [1981] and Adobe [1991]

An extract of [myfonts.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317114556/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/old-style-7/) description:

> The name Old Style No. 7 comes from a time when foundries released a variety of typefaces under one name. Linotype produced Old Style No. 7, which was based on an early 1870s typeface from the Bruce Typefoundry, which had based its design on a type from the Scottish foundry Miller and Richards.
